content: The Act is titled the "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" and its purpose is outlined in section 2. The "Jicarilla Apache Reservation Rural Water System Act" aims to ensure safe water supply and wastewater systems for residents of the Jicarilla Apache Reservation in New Mexico. It authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to plan, design, and construct these systems in collaboration with the Jicarilla Apache Nation. The Jicarilla Apache Nation aims to plan, design, and construct water supply, delivery, and wastewater systems on their reservation in New Mexico. This includes service connections to facilities in Dulce and the surrounding area, as well as individuals. The Secretary is required to enter into a self-determination contract with the Nation upon request. The Jicarilla Apache Nation requests the Secretary to enter into a self-determination contract for planning, designing, and constructing water supply and wastewater systems. JICARILLA APACHE RESERVATION RURAL WATER SYSTEM. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will construct the Rural Water Supply Project to improve water supply, delivery, and wastewater facilities in Dulce, New Mexico, and surrounding communities. The project includes facilities for water supply, delivery, and wastewater services for Dulce, Mundo Ranch Development, and surrounding areas on the Reservation. The Rural Water Supply Project will include distribution facilities, pipelines, pumping plants, and other necessary facilities to meet the water supply needs of the Reservation. SEC. 8. PROHIBITION ON USE OF FUNDS FOR IRRIGATION PURPOSES. None of the funds for the Rural Water Supply Project can be used for irrigation facilities. SEC. 9. WATER RIGHTS. The Jicarilla Apache Tribe Water Rights Settlement Act (Public Law 102-441) grants the Tribe water rights adjudicated under New Mexico State law. These rights provide water for the municipal water system and are recognized depletions within the San Juan River basin. The Rural Water Supply Project does not involve new depletions, as confirmed by Reclamation in consultation with the Fish and Wildlife Service. The Rural Water Supply Project will not impact any other water rights of the Jicarilla Apache Tribe, and there will be no significant impact on endangered species as a result of water depletions associated with the project.
